title: Research
text:
Human activity has led to rapid landscape changes that can alter the behavior of wild populations. However, it is unclear whether different populations exposed to similar anthropogenic environments adapt in similar ways. In this study, we used human-commensal populations of Oceanic Swallows as a model to assess how birds may adapt to living in close proximity to humans. To assess whether different, independently commensal populations exhibit evidence of parallel adaptation to human environments, we used FST, Pi, and Dxy to identify outlier regions differentiated between commensal and non-commensal populations. Aiding Sam Sudoko, Biology master’s student, I conducted these analyses and found several shared regions of high Fst in commensal populations that suggest parallel selection across different, independently commensal populations. By untangling the underlying genetic mechanisms of evolutionary adaptation within human-modified environments, this study will provide insight into how human activity can shape behaviors in wild populations.










Our knowledge about speciation is still largely biased towards terrestrial organisms, while most of this knowledge cannot be applied to marine speciation. However, Nudibranch speciation in particular is important to understand as these speciation event may be indicative of range shift, human influence, or introduction of invasive species. They serve as bioindicators, thus, maintaining an accurate, accessible record of their biodiversity enables us to make

title: Hello!
text: My name is Jordyn Scott (she/her), and I am a rising Senior at Cal Poly Pomona (Class of 2026), where I am majoring in Environmental Biology and minoring in Chemistry. As an undergraduate researcher, I work with both Dr. Elizabeth Scordato (human land use change’s impact on avian evolution) and Dr. Jayson Smith (anthropogenic stressors’ impact on intertidal organisms and ecological interactions).

title: Hello!
text: My name is Jordyn Scott (she/her), and I am a rising Senior at Cal Poly Pomona (Class of 2026), where I am majoring in Environmental Biology and minoring in Chemistry. As an undergraduate researcher, I work with both Dr. Elizabeth Scordato (human land use change’s impact on avian evolution) and Dr. Jayson Smith (anthropogenic stressors’ impact on intertidal organisms and ecological interactions).

title: Hello!
text:
Interests
I am interested in how urban and suburban environments, historical human land use change, and novel anthropogenic stressors impact the evolution, ecology, and behavior of marine and avian organisms.

title: Hello!
text:
Education
California State Polytechnic University, Pomona | Pomona, CA
B.S. in Environmental Biology, Minor in Chemistry | Aug 2022 - Present (Graduating Spring 2026!)
Cumulative GPA: 3.94
President’s List, Dean’s List (how many semesters?)
Folsom High School | Folsom, CA
Cumulative GPA: 4.21 | Graduated 2022






Hike in Volcano Baru National Park (Boquete, Panama) for Tropical Field Biology course






Sea otter skull dissection at California Academy of Sciences SSI REU






Horn shark egg case during intertidal biodiversity sampling






Tabling with CPP SACNAS at Riverside Insect Fair

title: Community and Outreach
text: I am also deeply committed to being a part of and fostering inclusive communities that support aspiring STEM students and promote diversification of STEM fields. To perpetuate this passion, I co-founded Cal Poly Pomona’s Society for the Advancement of Chicanos/Hispanics and Native Americans in Science (SACNAS) Chapter, and now lead the community as President. Our goal is to provide equitable access to academic resources, professional development workshops, volunteer opportunities, and research talks. I also work as a Dive Center Assisstant at CPP ASI Scuba Dive Center, where I build my leadership and safety skills in SCUBA as a Divemaster in Training and plan SCUBA certification trips and events to help develop students’ respect and admiration for the underwater world!

title: Community and Outreach
text:
Cal Poly Pomona

SACNAS Chapter

Co-Founder, President, and National Liaison (August 2024 - Present)

Initiated and led the registration process, collaboratively designed the Bylaws and Chapter Charter, attended leadership workshops, formatted and filled Executive Board positions, and completed all tasks necessary for the successful function and establishment of the club



Organize and lead Executive Board and General meetings, delegating tasks for events and meetings to ensure they run smoothly



Collaboratively designed events and delegated tasks for events:

Tabling: City of STEM and LA Maker Fair; Riverside Insect Fair; Cal Poly Pomona Club Fair; SACNAS Tabling Fundraiser
Professional Development: Resume Workshop; Personal Statement Workshop; DEIA Flash Talk & Pot Painting Social
Volunteering: collaboration with Kellogg Elementary, where members could assist classes with their semester long science projects and garden rehabilitation program; upcoming collaboration with ALMA to provide mentors (Cal Poly Pomona students) for high school students on the STEM pathway





Aquarium of the Pacific

2025 CELP Scholar and Volunteer

Engage in professional development workshops, shadow educational and diving programs, and present a lightning talk at the Scholar Symposium as a CELP Scholar recipient
Collaborated with other volunteers in the Horticulture program to help remove invasive plant species surrounding outside exhibits and replaced them with native plants and milkweed to help cultivate Monarch butterfly populations
Participated in the T.R.A.S.H. program and helped remove garbage from vulnerable coastal ecosystems




ASI Scuba Dive Center

Dive Center Assistant and Divemaster in Training (DMT) (November 2023 - Present)

Outline and schedule Scuba Certification trips to Channel Islands and the annual recreational Spring Break trip
Maintain student paperwork and engage with students in community-based scuba pool activities and training
Lead the monthly newsletter and organize interviews with academics and professionals engaged in scuba diving




Biology Assistant Program

Biology Learning Assistant (Spring 2024)

In-class assistant and outside tutor for Introductory Biology and Introductory Ecology courses; assissted professor with in-class activities and lesson plans to further enhance students’ learning
Independently held weekly tutoring hours, taught peers through real-world applications and lesson outlines; held 1:1 office hours to provide assistance




Science Council

Director of External Affairs (January 2024 - 2025)

Responsible for communication with >30 Science clubs on campus to ensure they are receiving the support needed for successful participation in Science Council events, including curating a monthly newsletter for students under the College of Science
Help plan and execute professional development workshops by outlining a schedule and the components needed to put on the event
Maintain data on club involvement to ensure clubs receive a budget that reflects their participation
